column9: Using 'will' to express certain future events
column11: He will never change his mind
column12: This will be a great year

column9: Using 'will' to make predictions about the future
column10: I think it will rain later

column9: Using 'going to' to express future plans
Using present continuous for future arrangements
column12: She's flying to London next week

column9: To be free from something unwanted
column10: He will never be rid of it
column11: I want to be rid of this problem
column12: They can't be rid of the responsibility

column9: To prevent someone from taking action
Keen or anxious to do something

column11: It may rule out that option
column12: The weather may rule our plans

column9: To be destined or supposed to
column10: You were meant to be here

column11: I wish I hadn't said that
column12: I wish you had told me

column9: Action continuing from past to present

column10: When I arrived, he had left
column11: She called after I had eaten
column12: They had finished before we came

column9: Action done to subject in past

column10: It's a pity that you can't come
column11: It's a pity that it rained
column12: It's a pity that we missed it

column10: What a pity you can't join us
column11: What a pity about the weather

column9: To feel sorry for and help someone
column10: They took pity on the stray cat
I pity those who never try

column9: Using present simple for general truths
column10: He hates and loves the ring
column11: The sun rises in the east

column9: Past state that is no longer true
column10: He used to be called John
column11: This used to be called New Amsterdam
column12: She used to be called by her nickname

column9: To make someone crazy or very angry
column11: This problem is driving her mad

column9: To cause or bring about death

column10: Even the wise cannot see all ends

column9: To have a role in future events
column10: You have some part to play
column11: Everyone has some part to play
column12: She has some part to play

column9: Whether the result is positive or negative
column10: It will affect us for good or ill
column11: Changes come for good or ill
column12: The decision, for good or ill

column9: To receive or be allocated something

column11: Opportunities that are given to us
column12: The tasks that are given to us

column10: There are other forces at work
column11: Other forces at work in the economy

column9: To be trapped or lodged behind something

column12: My phone is stuck behind the bed

column9: To drop or come out of something
column10: It fell out of my pocket
column11: The letter fell out of the book
column12: Money fell out of his wallet

column9: To become stuck firmly in place

column12: It became lodged between the seats

column12: They're not sure where to go

column9: To be worthy of receiving something
Expressing desire for change in others' behavior
column11: I wish it would stop raining

column10: So do all who face this

column9: Using present perfect for life experiences
Using past perfect for actions before another past event
column10: I had finished before you called
column11: She had left when I arrived
column12: They had eaten when we got there

column9: To assist or aid with something

column11: Never forget where you came from
